aboutSections.heading: We offset our carbon footprint
aboutSections.text: We are concerned about the environment and we take actions as a company to reduce and offset our CO2 emissions. We reduce our carbon emissions with our travel policy and other internal proposals. In addition, we offset our emissions through Atmosfair, an organization that develops and finances renewable energy.

aboutSections.heading: Travel policy: less plane, more train
aboutSections.text: The plane is the least environmentally friendly mode of transport, so we avoid them as much as possible. Our policy prioritizes the train when we travel within the same country. If taking a flight is unavoidable, we do it in economy class, which produces 2 to 3 times less CO2 than a business flight. In addition, our offices are located in places that are well connected by public transportation.

aboutSections.heading: We keep our office green
aboutSections.text: The sum of many small actions can have a big impact. Tiko has digitized most of the process of buying and selling a home, resulting in a considerable reduction of paper; only the necessary official documents are printed. And, of course, we are very serious about recycling. Additionally, our snacks at the office are always local. These are examples of some of the actions we take at the office.

Even if you’re not ready yet to commit to offsetting your extended footprint, it’s worth measuring it regularly and tracking changes.

requirements.description:
To calculate Scope 3 emissions, you need to use more sophisticated calculation tools than for Scope 1 and 2, as you should collect data about nearly all your business processes and products.

Consider these options from non-profit organizations: [Smart 3 by MyClimate](https://www.myclimate.org/information/news-press/news/newsdetail/a-management-tool-for-new-and-existing-partners-myclimate-smart-3/), [Climate Neutral](https://bee.climateneutral.org/)

You can also find calculation tools specialized in some product groups: food, travel, fashion, etc.
requirements.title: Calculate Scope 3 emissions

requirements.description:
It’s not a one-time action.You can start with 100% offsetting for the previous year, but in general it means that you include the costs of product offsetting in your prices and/or cut your margins. 
You can also negotiate with your suppliers and share offsetting costs with them. 

If you are not ready for such measures yet, you can offer your customers to buy products themselves or with additional offsetting prices. It’s the easiest and safest option, but it will not help you to cover even half of Scope 3 emissions.

completedCompanyActions.description: Greening your supply chain is an important way to scale your climate efforts.

requirements.description:
Use your purchasing power to influence industry:
- __Policies and codes:__ Set supply chain policies and codes aligned with your own environmental standards, as well as universal standards. Make these standards a consideration when selecting new suppliers, and part of your regular conversation with suppliers.
- __Suppliers qualification and engagement: __Review all your suppliers and look to buy from companies that are also operating with climate emergency conditions guiding their strategy. Gearing the supply chain to achieve the organization’s climate commitments is a key step. The goal must be to create a ‘coalition of the willing’. [Here](https://www.epa.gov/climateleadership/center-corporate-climate-leadership-how-engage-suppliers) you can find an example of a questionnaire and some advice on how to engage suppliers.
- __Energy usage:__ Encourage your suppliers to switch to using renewable electricity and biogas.
- __Keep updated and cooperate:__ send an annual letter to all your suppliers to share details about your environmental policy updates and achievements in carbon footprint reduction. Conduct a supplier survey and offer suppliers a space to record comments and provide feedback.
 
Mark this action as complete if you have done qualification for at least a group of Significant Suppliers (who collectively represent approximately 80% of your purchases in currency terms). Significant Suppliers can include both suppliers of physical items and service providers like accountants and web designers. 

__Use responsible materials:__
- Review all the materials used in your manufacturing processes and shift to the most responsible (and least impactful) materials.
- Use reusable or recycled materials where possible. 
- Undertake a full Life Cycle Analysis (LCA) on your products.
- Improve the End-of-Life process for your product.

For a more in-depth guide on managing impact within your supply chain, you can check out [Creating Impact Through Purchasing](http://go.pardot.com/l/39792/2017-04-12/6pfr3q/39792/130791/Creating_Impact_Through_Purchasing___Best_Practice_Guide.pdf) made by B Labs.

requirements.description:
For domestic routes under five hours by train, take the train.
Railway stations are often more centrally located than airports, which makes arrival and departure easier and reduces the footprint of using taxis.  

Mark this action as completed as soon as you change your corporate travel policy accordingly.
requirements.title: Trains over planes policy

requirements.description:
For intercontinental travel, a seat in business class produces __two to three times__ as much CO2 as an economy seat. 
First-class seats even produce up to __six times__ as much CO2.

Mark this action as completed as soon as you change your corporate travel policy and make sure that you buy only economy class tickets from now on.
